nodes.bodyText: If you're planning to delete the async tests and inline the base classes into the sync tests, why not do that first? It would make changes like this much easier to make (and to review 😉).
I'll delete all the async tests and the base test classes in the next commit 😄
Removed most async and base class combinations, I'll hold off on removing the rest for another PR since the few that are left contain more technical details I don't want to handle in this PR.
Does this encode to a URL-safe variant of Base64? Document keys can be used in URL paths, so certain characters used in vanilla Base64 are not allowed.

Appears that I need to use Base64.getUrlEncoder, that will be URL safe 😄
https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/java/util/Base64.html#getUrlEncoder--
If the URL encoded characters of + and / are expected on the service side this could be wrapped in a called to URLEncode instead.
The service doesn't interpret or try to decode the document key (at least not in this API). It's just that the client needs to construct a valid URL that the service will understand.

Changing the casing of these fields/accessors is moving this class further away from its intended purpose (not that it ever properly fulfilled its purpose in the Java tests).
In the Track 1 .NET SDK, LoudHotel is used to test scenarios where a customer has implemented their own custom attributes that they use to control how model property names serialize/deserialize to index field names. For LoudHotel specifically, the corresponding index definition has camelCase field names, while LoudHotel has ALLCAPS property names.
If I understand correctly, @JsonProperty is part of a JSON library for Java and not something a customer would implement themselves, so this class isn't really fulfilling its intended purpose anyway. Are customer-authored attributes a thing when it comes to Java serialization (@JonathanGiles )? If not, we need to rethink this class.
If we keep this class though, the accessor/field names should be ALLCAPS or it isn't really "loud" anymore, is it? 😁
No, the JSON is expected to have camelCase property names (at least, it is in .NET -- looks like the Java tests were setup for PascalCase instead).
Reverting the changes made to this class and will add a linting suppression to this class
Thank you very much for doing this. 👍 Good docs are so important!

nodes.bodyText: I'm assuming that Arrays.asList(null, null) is returning an ArrayList of Object, not String. This is fine (since this SDK has never shipped, there are no backcompat concerns), but the comment and name of the test no longer reflect reality.
I'll update this to make sure it uses List<String>.
Looks like the bug from the Track 1 tests got ported over. This should be uploading indexedDoc, not expectedDoc.
Removed this class
Should be uploading indexedDoc. I'm getting paranoid now that we've made this mistake in many places and copy-pasted. 😬
Using indexDoc now
Why do we remove the getCoordinates?
It was an ask to remove them, #8149
It's been a general guideline to include a message on Objects.requireNonNull calls.
I changed the API and document in my PR

nodes.bodyText: Why do we remove this API?
Per request from Bruce, it will be easier to add this back in the future than removing it from our APIs.
